comment.author: 23103743@N05
23103743@N05
comment._content: Her personal life was clearly as newsworthy as her professional life. The Evening Independent - Dec 13, 1921 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19211213&i... has a long piece suggesting that her marriage to the wealthy artist Ben Ali Haggin might be on the rocks. It mentions that here first marriage was in 1911, when she eloped with a Harvard student, Graham Glass, Jr. The article covers a foursome, Bonnie, her husband, her former dancing partner, Al Davis, and his wealthy wife, the former Eugenie Kelly. The Ogden standard-examiner., December 31, 1922, The Standard - Examiner Sunday Feature Section, Image 25 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-12-31/ed-... a full-page spread headlined, "And What Will Pretty Bonnie Glass Do Now?" This piece indicates that she and her husband had separated and suggests she might marry her former partner, Al Davis.

comment._content: LoC has plenty of pictures of her as Mrs. Ben Ali Haggin (some in the Bain collection but not yet up on Flickr) www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=ben%20ali%20haggin&st=... One of the Bain photos not yet on Flickr www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2006000776/resource/ is identified in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Red_Cross_Pageant as of the National Red Cross Pageant, October 1917. The wikipedia page includes a cast list with roles for the entire pageant. Bonnie Glass/Helen Roche/Mrs Ben Ali Haggin appears to have danced the pavane with a former partner Clifton Webb. The pageant was "the brainchild" of her husband.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
@swanq: Thanks for diving back into Bain so quickly after the U.S. government shutdown ended. 
You've gathered an impressive variety of sources to round out the story of Bonnie Glass' life, and opened new doors to information by connecting her to her two other names. The full-length color sketch by Everett Shinn brings a nice touch of color & attitude into the story. I don't know clothing styles well enough to fully confirm your observation, but the blue outfit in the sketch sure seems similar to the dress in the Bain photo--at least both show buttons along the bottom of the sleeve along with the fur.  Welcome back! -- Helena (LOC)
